body_text.text: Innate immunity is a critical frontline host defense mechanism in response to pathogen infection.

At the onset of infections in vertebrates, a set of more than 400 genes are transcriptionally upregulated 51 by interferon and thus termed interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs). ISGs display diverse functions such 52 as activation of cell death programs and recruitment of immune cells (e.g. dendritic cells (Schneider et To investigate MISTRAV biology, we generated three A549 clonal cell lines -C15∆1, C15∆2, C15∆3 -182 with distinct indels that disrupted the MISTRAV ORF using CRISPR/CAS ( Figure 3A ). A549 cells were 183 selected because: 1) MISTRAV is interferon-inducible in these cells ( Figure 1D , Figure

RT-PCR indicated that C15∆1 and C15∆2 cells lack full-length (FL) MISTRAV RNA expression in 192 IFN-g treated cells at steady-state while C15∆3 cells display a fortuitous and drastic increase of the same 193 transcript ( Figure 3C ). miRNA qPCR demonstrated that C15∆1 and C15∆2, maintain miR-147b at levels 194 comparable to wild-type with expression of miR-147b in C15∆3 ~30 fold greater than WT ( Figure 3D ).
Thus, C15∆1 and C15∆2 lack MISTRAV protein but maintain the miRNA, while C15∆3 lacks MISTRAV 196 with a gain-of-function of miR-147b expression.

Based on MISTRAV mitochondrial localization and numerous documented connections between 198 immune responses involving cell death mediated through mitochondria, we reasoned that MISTR might 199 mediate apoptotic responses. We primed WT and KO cells with IFN-g then added the commonly used 200 activator of apoptosis, staurosporine (STS), for 16 hours followed by functional analysis ( Figure 3E ).

Assays were normalized to either untreated controls or to the number of cells being tested to account for 202 differences in proliferation rates (Figure 3-figure supplement 1) . Interestingly, we observed that C15∆1 203 and C15∆2 displayed reduced sensitivity to STS, while C15∆3 showed increased sensitivity to STS 204 compared to WT cells ( Figure 3F ). Consistent with these results, we detected robust caspase-3/7 205 cleavage activity for C15∆3 compared to WT ( Figure 3G ; p<0.0001). In addition, detectable decreases in 206 caspase-3/7 activity were observed for C15∆1 and C15∆2 relative to WT treated cells ( Figure 3G ; 207 p<0.0001). The differential sensitivities of the clones to STS relative to WT were consistent with levels of 9 PARP cleavage across the clones in response to STS ( Figure 3H ). These data suggest a role for 209 MISTRAV and miR-147b in apoptosis.

FIGREF0.text: 53 al., 2014; Schoggins, 2014). Although the identities of many of these genes are established, the functions 54 of the majority of these gene products as well as their relationship with other cellular factors is unknown 55 (Schoggins et al., 2011; 2014). To dissect the function of poorly characterized ISGs, we used a 56 comparative approach to identify signatures of positive selection consistent with important functional roles 57 in immune responses (Daugherty and Malik, 2012). Specifically, we sought to identify ISGs lacking known 58 functions with hallmarks of repeated conflicts with pathogens, like those detected for interferon-inducible 59 double-stranded RNA sensor oligoadenylate synthetase 1 (OAS1), which in addition to signatures of 60 rapid evolution (Hancks et al., 2015; Mozzi et al., 2015) are also encoded in virus genomes (Darby et al.,61 2014).

FIGREF1.text: Viruses can encode proteins that mimic host proteins to manipulate cellular functions and63 inactivate immune defenses. This form of mimicry is commonly achieved by the acquisition of a host-64 coding sequence through horizontal gene transfer (HGT) followed by subfunctionalization via cycles of 119 Subsequent database searches detected another MISTR ORF (TetV-113/AUF82205.1), 120 hereafter vMISTR Algae (vMISTRA), in the genome of the giant DNA virus (Schvarcz and Steward, 2018) 121 Tetraselmis virus 1 (TetV-1) -a mimivirid -that infects the cosmopolitan green alga Tetraselmis (Figure 122 1C). vMISTRA encodes a predicted 83 AA ORF with a primary structure similar to MISTRAV and 123 vMISTRAV: short N-terminus, predicted single-pass TMEM domain, longer C-terminal domain, and a 124 B12D domain spanning these features. A clustal amino acid alignment using three Tetraselmis MISTR 125 protein sequences from the database indicates that vMISTRA displays the greatest homology with126A0A061RM32 in UniProt (40% identity by blastp)(Figure 1-figure supplement 1A-B). Thus, sequences 127 resembling MISTR proteins are encoded by viruses that infect hosts from algae to mammals.

FIGREF2.text: immune signals such as interferon. To test whether MISTRAV is an ISG, we performed 131 RT-PCR on samples from various human and mouse cell lines treated with either Type I (IFN-a) or Type 132 II Interferon (IFN-g). While MISTRAV is induced by IFN-a in A549 lung epithelial cells, our data indicate 133 that MISTRAV is primarily upregulated by IFN-g in the human and mouse cell lines tested (Figure 1D).134Thus, MISTRAV displays two key hallmarks of crucial immune factors like OAS1: upregulation by immune 135 signals and viral homologs (vMISTRAV, vMISTRA).

FIGREF3.text: Both human and mouse (known as AA467197) MISTRAV have evidence for mitochondrial 137 localization. The inventory of mammalian mitochondrial genes -MitoCarta (Calvo et al., 2016; Pagliarini 138 et al., 2008) -detected MISTRAV in mitochondria across various tissues: small intestine, large intestine, 139 stomach, placenta, and testis. In addition, MISTRAV is related to two known mitochondrial factors 140 (MISTR1 and MISTRH) thought to be supernumerary factors associated with the electron transport chain 141 (Balsa et al., 2012; Floyd et al., 2016; Tello et al., 2011). Consistent with previous findings, our expression 142 of MISTRAV-GFP and vMISTRAV-GFP in HeLa cells revealed strong co-localization with the 143 mitochondrial marker, MitoTracker (Figure 1E). Intriguingly, vMISTRAV-GFP expression in some cells 144 resulted in altered morphology of the cell and/or mitochondria (Figure 1E). 145 MISTRAV belongs to a gene family rapidly evolving in primates 146 MISTRAV and its poorly characterized paralogs MISTR1 and MISTRH -are conserved over 450 147 million years of evolution as evidenced by the presence of orthologs in the zebrafish and spotted gar 148 genomes (Figure 2-figure supplement 1). To gain insights into the recent evolution of all three MISTR 149 proteins, we carried out evolutionary analysis using sequences for primate orthologs spanning more than 150 35 million years of divergence (Figure 2, Supplementary file 1, Supplementary file 6). Specifically, we 151 tested if MISTR proteins display elevated rates of nonsynonymous amino acid substitution relative to 152 synonymous substitution rates (dN/dS > 1) to determine if these proteins are likely to be engaged in 153 genetic conflicts with pathogen-encoded inhibitors (McLaughlin and Malik, 2017) (Daugherty and Malik, gene-wide rapid evolution patterns. Furthermore, these signatures in MISTRAV and MISTR1 159 appear independent of any potential relaxed constraint within the predicted transmembrane (TMEM) 160 domain as the signal is maintained when that domain is removed in additional tests [MISTRAV -M7 vs. 161 M8 (F3X4) p < 0.0040, MISTR1 -M7 vs. M8 (F3X4) p < 0.0040]. Calculating dN/dS values across the 162 primate phylogeny using PAML identified multiple, distinct lineages in all three primate families 163 [Hominoids (HOM), Old World Monkeys (OWM), and New World Monkeys (NWM)] with robust and 164 recurrent signatures of rapid evolution for both MISTRAV and MISTR1. 165 Signatures of positive selection at specific amino acid residues can reveal key protein surfaces 166 targeted by pathogen-encoded inhibitors and the number of surfaces with elevated dN/dS values is 167 hypothesized to correlate with the number of interfaces (Daugherty and Malik, 2012). Using PAML (Yang, 168 2007), MEME (Murrell et al., 2012), FUBAR (Murrell et al., 2013)], we estimated dN/dS per amino acid 169 site for MISTR genes. These analyses (Figure 2D, Figure 2E, Figure 2F) revealed seven different amino 170 acid positions (~8% of the whole-protein) distributed through MISTRAV with evidence of positive selection 171 including two sites (21T and 79Q) identified by all three analyses. For MISTR1, three amino acid positions 172were predicted for rapid evolution owing to elevated dN/dS values, with 6I being notable for its detection 173 by all three analyses.

FIGREF4.text: Protein modeling with SWISS-MODEL (https://swissmodel.expasy.org/)(Waterhouse et al., 175 2018)(Figure 2G, Figure 2H, Figure 2I) using the only predicted structure of Complex IV to include 176 MISTR1 [PDB:5Z62] (Zong et al., 2018) illustrates that MISTR TMEM domains are accessible for 177 interfacing with cellular proteins. Thus, rapid evolution in the TMEM is unlikely to reflect relaxed 178 constraint. Collectively, the rapid evolution signature observed for MISTRAV and MISTR1 resemble that 179 of other host factors that can dictate the outcomes of infections.

FIGREF6.text: used as a model for immune activation (Li et al., 2017), and relatedly, 3) this cell line is frequently 185 used to model viral infections (Li et al., 2016) (e.g. coronaviruses, influenza, poxviruses). Consistent with 186 the engineered mutations (Figure 3A), western blot analysis confirmed loss of MISTRAV protein in all 187 three clones (Figure 3B). To maintain expression of a poorly characterized miRNA encoded by the 3'-188 UTR of MISTRAV (miR-147b) (Liu et al., 2009), we targeted the guide RNAs to exon 2 relative to the 189 long MISTRAV isoform (Figure 3A, 875 nt) -a location where a frameshift in the RNA would be predicted 190 to escape nonsense-mediated decay.

FIGREF7.text: insights into the increased levels of apoptosis in C15∆3 cells associated with miR-147b 212 [miR-147 in mouse (Liu et al., 2009)] we performed comparative miRNA target analysis. A recent survey 213indicates that the miR-147b seed sequence is conserved in vertebrate orthologs (Bartel, 2018).

FIGREF8.text: Strikingly, our sequence analysis demonstrated that all twenty-two nucleotides of miR-147b miRNA are 215 identical between human and spotted gar; which represents around 450 million years of divergence from216 a common ancestor (Figure 4). Interestingly, although the MISTRAV locus is present in the zebrafish 217 genome, miR-147b sequence is likely non-functional because of disruptive indels (Figure analysis uncovered 36 [(mirdb.org)(Wong and Wang, 2015)(Liu and Wang, 2019)] 220 and 19 [Targetscan (www.targetscan.org) (Agarwal et al., 2015)] miR-147b predicted targets 221 (Supplementary files 2 and 3), of which only two were shared by both databases: C11orf87 and the 222 MISTRAV paralog, MISTR1. The predicted miRNA response elements (MRE) in the 3'-UTR of the 223 MISTRAV paralog, MISTR1, is a predicted 8mer seed that is perfectly conserved out to fish genomes 224 (Figure 4). In addition, 1) the 8mer has duplicated in some fish MISTR1 orthologs (e.g. gar and 225 medaka)(Figure 4) and 2) zebrafish maintains the predicted MRE for miR-147b. 226 Interestingly, the predicted MRE encoded by MISTR1 overlaps with an MRE for an unrelated 227 miRNA, miR-210. miR-210 is highly upregulated by HIF1a during low oxygen conditions and thought to 228 be critical for the hypoxic response (Huang et al., 2009). Assays using a MRE reporter encoding the 229 human MISTR1 (NDUFA4) 3'-UTR (Bertero et al., 2012) support the functionality of this shared MRE, yet 230 the significance has remained an open question. Evolutionary analysis indicates that the miR-210 seed 231 is perfectly conserved in bilateria for sequences sampled, with 19/22 nucleotides identical between the 232 human and Drosophila orthologs (Figure 4) and 21/22 nts identical between human and fish orthologs.

FIGREF9.text: 233Thus, the MISTR1 3'-UTR encodes a highly conserved MRE potentially targeted by two distinct 10 ultraconserved miRNAs with an overlapping seed sequence; one of which is encoded by the paralog 235 MISTRAV.

FIGREF10.text: seven MREs in the MISTR1 3'-UTR for six distinct miRNAs [miR-7-5p, miR-238 145-5p (2 sites), miR-147b-3p, miR-202-5p, miR-205-5p and miR-210-3p], which have seed sequences 239 that are highly conserved in vertebrates with a subset extending in sequence conservation to bilateria 240 (Figure 5A)(Bartel, 2018). MRE reporter assays using a luciferase reporter with the entire 1685 bp human 241 MISTR1 3'-UTR (Figure 5B) revealed that transient co-transfection of either miR-7-5p, miR-147b-3p, 242 miR-210-3p in HEK293T cells resulted in dramatic knockdown (40-65% of vector alone).

FIGREF11.text: Correspondingly, western blots with lysates from HEK293T and A549 cells transiently transfected with244 miR-7-5p, miR-147b-3p, miR-210-3p (Figure 5C) demonstrated knockdown of endogenous MISTR1 245 protein. We identified two polyA signal canonical hexamers (AATAAA; 161-166, 1666-1671 relative to 246 human 3'-UTR) in the MISTR1 3'-UTR that divides the first four MREs from the three downstream sites 247 (Figure 5A). Interestingly, the miRNAs that did not result in knockdown are located downstream of the 248 first polyA signal while those that did cause knockdown of targets are located upstream of the first polyA 249 signal. Therefore, the MISTR1 3'-UTR encodes several predicted MREs for conserved miRNAs, of which 250 a subset is functional in cell culture assays.

FIGREF12.text: To test if MISTR1 is downregulated by stress, we performed western blots on lysates from A549 252 WT and MISTRAV A549 KO cells treated with STS and/or interferon. We observed a progressive253 downregulation of MISTR1 following treatment with STS or STS/IFN-g compared to IFN-g alone (Figure 254 5D). We also observed a nearly complete loss of MISTR1 in C15∆3 mutant cells, which overexpress miR-255 147b. MISTR1 downregulation appears either specific or rapid in comparison to levels of the 256 mitochondrial Complex II protein SDHA, which are largely unchanged under the same conditions (Figure 257 5D). These data suggest loss of MISTR1 may promote apoptosis under conditions of stress. To test this 258 hypothesis directly, we generated two MISTR1 KO A549 clonal cell lines (N21 and N31)(Figure 5, figure 259 supplement 1). A control experiment showed that MISTR1 KO cells exhibit rates of proliferation similar 260 to WT (Figure 5-figure supplement 1D). Assay of these cells following STS treatment using live-cell analysis with the IncuCyte and western blot for cleaved PARP indicates that MISTR1 KO cells are more 262 sensitive to this apoptotic trigger compared to WT cells (Figure 5E, Figure 5-figure supplement 1E).

FIGREF13.text: Next, we examined regulation of MISTR1 in cells under hypoxic stress; a condition when miR-264 210 and MISTR1's paralog, MISTRH (Tello et al., 2011), are expressed. Following the induction of 265 chemical hypoxia by deferoxamine mesylate (DFO) treatment in three cell lines, we observed 266 downregulation of MISTR1 concomitant with an upregulation of HIF1α, MISTRH (Figure 5F), and miR-267 210 (Figure 5G). Analysis of RCC4 kidney cancer cells with and without Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor 268 suppressor indicate that the opposing expression of MISTR1 and MISTRH requires HIF signaling (Figure 269 5H). Thus, MISTR1 is downregulated by ultraconserved stress-induced miRNAs under conditions when 270 its paralogs are upregulated.

FIGREF14.text: broad phylogenetic distribution of MISTR proteins 272 To examine the implications of our findings in an evolutionary context, we characterized the breadth of 273 MISTR proteins across eukaryotic genomes. While a recent study detected MISTR1 homologs in yeasts, 274 including Baker's and fission yeast, as well Plasmodium (Balsa et al., 2012), major gaps in the distribution 275 and evolution of these proteins remain. We identified additional predicted proteins across animals and 276 plants displaying homology to MISTR variants (Supplementary file 4). These data indicate MISTRAV, 277 MISTR1, MISTRH sequences are conserved in vertebrate genomes with duplications present in the 278 zebrafish genome for MISTR1 and MISTRH; a phenomenon common to genes of teleost fish (Howe et 279 al., 2013).

FIGREF15.text: Maximum-likelihood phylogenetic analysis using PhyML (Guindon et al., 2010) of these AA 281 sequences defines three major clades: A) vertebrate MISTRAVs, B) vertebrate MISTR1 and MISTRHs 282 as well as Nematostella and Drosophila proteins, and C) plant MISTRs along with algae and yeast 283 proteins (Balsa et al., 2012). Low bootstrap values observed throughout the tree may be a consequence 284 of the small length of MISTR sequences (i.e. too few characters) despite generating one-thousand trees 285 for bootstrap analysis.

FIGREF16.text: 286The clustering of vMISTRAV between the clade representing MISTRAV from mammals and 287 lineages leading to chicken and zebrafish support the notion that vMISTRAV 1) likely originated from a12 mammalian host in agreement with the primary host of squirrelpox (Darby et al., 2014) and diverged 289 substantially after horizontal gene transfer and 2) is derived from host MISTRAV and not MISTR1 or 290 MISTRH. A similar placement of vMISTRA from TetV-1 near MISTR sequence from the Tetraselmis algae 291 protein (A0A061RM32) is also consistent with horizontal transfer from host to virus. Interestingly, the 292 choanoflagellate Salpingoeca rosetta encodes two divergent MISTR homologs as evidenced by 293 XP_004989268.1 clustering with Clade B and XP_004998377.1 clustering with Clade C. These data 294 indicate that MISTR is widely distributed in genomes of diverse eukaryotes and has undergone repeated 295 diversification, including ancestral duplications, as well as more recent evolutionary innovations.

FIGREF17.text: indicate a role for MISTR in cellular stress responses. To test the ability of vMISTRAV to 298 counteract these responses, we engineered cells stably expressing the squirrelpox protein with a C-299 terminal HA epitope tag (Figure 7A). vMISTRAV-expressing cells grow at the same rate as control cells 300 expressing an empty vector (EV) (Figure 7-figure supplement 1A). When vMISTRAV cells were treated 301 with three activators of apoptosis -STS, actinomycin D (ActD), and camptothecin (CPT), we observed a 302 protective effect of vMISTRAV as indicated by marked decreases in Caspase 3/7 activity (% apoptosis) 303 (Figure 7C, Figure 7D, Figure 7E) as well as decreases in percentage of cleaved PARP (Figure 7-figure 304supplement 1B) compared to EV controls. We therefore conclude that the virus-encoded vMISTRAV

FIGREF18.text: 305inhibits apoptosis triggered by distinct mechanisms, consistent with a newly described host-pathogen 306 conflict for control over the persistence of virus-infected cells.

FIGREF19.text: displays hallmarks of a critical immune defense function 309 Here we characterized a combination of features common to crucial immune factors to discover 310 how conserved, but mostly uncharacterized cellular proteins can mediate the key host defense process 311 of apoptosis. It is known that a subset of ISGs provide critical defenses against invading pathogens 312 (Schneider et al., 2014; Schoggins, 2014). However, of the more than 400 ISGs identified to date, the 313 majority are poorly characterized (Schoggins et al., 2011; 2014). Therefore, a high priority of 13 immunological research is to assign functions, define interactions, and uncover regulatory mechanisms 315 for this collection of vital gene products.

FIGREF20.text: work showing that MISTRAV is induced by other immune signals: LPS, poly I:C, and 318 PAM3SCK4 in primary mouse and human macrophage cell lines (Liu et al., 2009), LPS in human primary 319 effector dendritic cells (Zimmer et al., 2012), and IFN-a (Schoggins et al., 2011). Several lines of evidence 320 suggest that cellular MISTRAV is targeted for inactivation by multiple pathogens. Specifically, signatures 321 of rapid evolution we detected in primate genomes for MISTRAV (Figure 2A, Figure 2D) point to repeated 322 antagonistic interactions with pathogens on multiple protein surfaces. Although the precise functions of 323 the three MISTRAV domains remain undefined (N-terminus, transmembrane domain, and C-terminus), 324 all display evolutionary patterns consistent with genetic conflicts (Barber and Elde, 2014)(Elde et al., 325 2008; Sawyer et al., 2004). We predict that rapidly evolving surfaces on opposite sides of the TMEM, 326 which may be otherwise shielded by the mitochondrial inner membrane, represent unique surfaces 327 targeted by pathogen-encoded inhibitors.

FIGREF21.text: While positive selection predicts direct inhibitors of MISTRAV and MISTR1 functions, the 329 presence of two viral homologs (vMISTRAV and vMISTRA) supports the idea that viruses also counteract 330 this defense pathway via mimicry. Independent acquisition of related proteins by viruses that infect highly 331 divergent hosts appears to be extremely rare with the largest evolutionary span thus far being distinct 332 copies of IL-10 encoded by herpesviruses which infect fish and mammals(Ouyang et al., 2014). To our 333 knowledge, these are the first ETC-associated genes known to be acquired by viruses. These334 observations indicate that the MISTR pathway provides a vital cellular defense that can influence the 335 outcome of infections. Consistent with this idea, we demonstrate the ability of vMISTRAV to curb 336 apoptotic responses from stimuli that function by distinct mechanisms (Figure 7). Notably, while 337 MISTRAV, OAS1 (Hancks et al., 2015; Mozzi et al., 2015), cGAS, MX1 (Mitchell et al., 2012), 338 APOBEC3G (Sawyer et al., 2004), ZAP (Daugherty et al., 2014; Kerns et al., 2008), BST (tetherin) (Lim 339 et al., 2010; McNatt et al., 2009) and PKR (Elde et al., 2008) are all rapidly evolving and upregulated by the electron transport chain and stress responses 343 MISTR1 has been shown to associate with ETC complexes and was presumed to act as a 344 structural component of the complex, but additional functional roles are a matter of debate (Balsa et al., 345 2012; Kadenbach, 2017; Pitceathly and Taanman, 2018; Pitceathly et al., 2013). MISTR1 loss-of-function 346 caused by a homozygous splice donor mutation is associated with the neurological disorder Leigh's 347 syndrome (Pitceathly et al., 2013). MISTR1's annotation as NDUFA4 comes from initial findings that it 348 co-purifies with Complex I (Carroll et al., 2006). More recent work provided evidence for a primary 349 Complex IV association (Balsa et al., 2012). The presence of MISTR1 on the external surface (Figure 350 2J) of Complex IV was interpreted as a means of regulating higher-order ETC complex formation into 351 supercomplexes (Zong et al., 2018). Our data implicate downregulation of MISTR1 as a critical step for 352 cells to respond to stresses, including pathogen infections (Figure 5). High levels of conservation of 353 MISTR1 MREs for miR-210 and miR-147b (Figure 4) suggest the necessity of downregulating MISTR1 354 during immune signaling and hypoxia (Figure 5). 355 MISTR is a vertebrate specific stress response circuit 356 Integrating evolutionary analysis with experimental genetics and related functional analysis led us to 357 define a model for the MItochondrial STress Response circuit (MISTR)(Figure 7F). While some previous 358 studies hinted at potential interactions for MISTR components, functional connections were largely 359 unknown. For instance, miR-147b and miR-210 were shown to share a seed sequence and these 360 miRNAs can downregulate a MRE reporter encoding the MISTR1 3'-UTR when transfected (Bertero et 361 al., 2012). In addition, miR-147b functions were recently associated with the TCA cycle (Zhang et al., 362 2019), but the observation that miR-147b was encoded by the same gene as a MISTR1 paralog had not 363 been reported (Bertero et al., 2012)(Figure 4). Likewise, the overexpression of endogenous MISTRH 364 correlating with loss of MISTR1 protein (Figure 5H) has been observed in clear cell Renal Cell Carcinoma 365 (ccRCC) tumor samples and ccRCC cell lines (Minton et al., 2016); a disease characterized by hyperactive HIF signaling (Brugarolas, 2014), but the requirement of HIF in the regulation of this newly 367

FIGREF22.text: 370 inducible paralogs to facilitate apoptosis or some form of stress tolerance. Striking conservation of the 371 miRNAs targeting MISTR1 and cognate MREs (Figure 4) indicate MISTR-like responses are likely 372 common in many diverse vertebrate species. In sharp contrast, MISTRAV is rapidly evolving near the C-373 terminus approximately only 80-100 bases upstream of the ultraconserved miR-147b.

FIGREF23.text: Specifically, processing of miR-147b from the MISTRAV RNA, in principle, could uncouple the mRNA 376 cap from the polyA tail rendering translation of MISTRAV infeasible. Consistent with this prediction and 377 our findings, MISTRAV and miR-147b likely have related but separate functions (Figure 3). Furthermore, 378 post-transcriptional mechanisms might also regulate mature miR-147b activity or its ability to target 379 MISTR1. Strikingly, despite the high levels of miR-147b in C15∆3 (Figure 3D), including at baseline, gross 380 downregulation of MISTR1 -associated with the gain-of-function mutation in C15∆3 -does not occur until381STS is present (Figure 5D).

FIGREF24.text: In contrast to MISTRAV/miR-147b, miR-210 and MISTRH are encoded at distinct loci in an 383 arrangement more permissive to complementary functions. However, miR-210 is located within an intron 384 of an uncharacterized non-coding RNA -called miR-210HG in humans. Here, processing of miR-210 385 would not be predicted to inactivate the host gene. Therefore, miR-210 and miR-210HG may share 386 currently uncharacterized complementary functions. The distinct arrangements of miR-147b and miR-387 210 are consistent with differences in cellular responses to hypoxia and infection. Namely, under hypoxia 388 the cell will buffer itself from low-oxygen conditions enabling survival, while during infections there are 389 more drastic, escalating levels of responses culminating in apoptosis to eliminate virus infected cells.

FIGREF25.text: Putting these findings together, the MItochondrial STress Response (MISTR) system represents an 391 evolutionarily dynamic circuit interfacing with fundamental cellular processes to mediate stress responses 392 that can be targeted by viruses.

Analyses 405 were also performed using MEME (Murrell et al., 2012) and FUBAR (Murrell et al., 2013) from 406 Datamonkey (datamonkey.org) (Weaver et al., 2018) to predict rapidly evolving sites. Additional summary 407 of findings is present in the Supplementary file 6.

FIGREF29.text: Phylogenetic analysis was performed using PhyML. Model selection was performed by Smart Model 413 Selection (SMS)(Lefort et al., 2017) integrated into PhyML. The LG +G model was selected for tree 414 building using 1000 bootstrap replicates. FigTree v1.4.2 (http://tree.bio.ed.ac.uk/software/figtree/) was 415 used for tree visualization.

The 20 µL cDNA reaction was 433 subsequently diluted with water to a final volume of 100 µL. 1-2 µL of cDNA was used for 25 µL PCR 434 reactions using the GoTaq Hot Start Master Mix (Promega). Cycling parameters consisted of an initial 435 denaturation of 95°C for 2 min., followed by 28-30 cycles of 95°C for 30s, 50°C for 30s, 72°C for 30s 436 finishing with a final elongation of 72°C 2 min. 20 µL of each PCR product was resolved by 2% agarose 437 gel electrophoresis and visualized using ethidium bromide.

Guide RNAs were positioned in exon 2 (long isoform) with the expectation based on rules of 442 nonsense-mediated decay such that frame-shifts here would be predicted to disrupt the MISTRAV ORF 443 while maintaining expression of miR-147b. A549 cells were transfected with the gRNA construct, followed 444 by puromycin (Invivogen) selection. Subsequently, limited dilution was performed to establish clonal cell 445 lines. Clones of interest were identified by PCR on genomic DNA harvested with the Quick-DNA Miniprep Kit (Zymo) from expanded cell lines using primers flanking exon 2 followed by Sanger sequencing of 447 amplicons by Genewiz. For MISTR1 KOs, guide RNAs (IDT) were transfected with Cas9 and tracRNA 448 from IDT into A549 cells. FIGREF34.text: were collected and lysed with RIPA Lysis and Extraction Buffer (ThermoFisher) supplemented with 457 1X Halt Protease Inhibitor Cocktail (ThermoFisher). For the HIF1a Western blots, nuclear fractions were 458 extracted using Abcam's Nuclear Fractionation Protocol. Cells cultured in 10-cm dishes were scraped in 459 500 µL of ice-cold Buffer A (10 mM HEPES, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 10 mM KCl, 0.5 mM DTT, 0.05% NP40, pH460 7.9, 1X Halt Protease Inhibitor Cocktail), transferred to 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes, and incubated on 461 ice for 10 min. Lysates were centrifuged at 4°C at 3,000 rpm for 10 minutes. Each pellet was 462 resuspended in 374 µL ice-cold Buffer B (5 mM HEPES, 1.5 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM EDTA, 0.5 mM DTT, 463 26% glycerol (v/v), pH 7.9, 1X Halt Protease Inhibitor Cocktail) and 26 µL of 4.6M NaCl (final NaCl 464 concentration: 300 mM), homogenized using a syringe with a narrow-gauge needle (27G), and incubated 465 on ice for 30 minutes. Lysates were centrifuged at 4°C at 24,000 x g for 20 min. The supernatant 466 containing the nuclear fraction was transferred to a new tube. Protein concentrations of the extracts were 467 measured using a Bradford assay. Protein samples were subjected to SDS-PAGE and wet-transferred 468 to a 0.2 µM Immobilon-PSQ PVDF membrane (Millipore) at 200 mA for 90 minutes. Membranes were 469 blocked with blocking buffer (5% BSA or milk in TBST) for 1 hour at RT, and then incubated with primary 470 antibodies at 4°C overnight. The following primary antibodies were used: SDHA (D6J9M) XP Rabbit 471 mAB (CST), PARP (CST), NDUFA4 (ThermoFisher), IDO (Novus Biologicals), C15orf48 (Aviva Systems 472 Biology), HA (Sigma), NDUFA4L2 (ThermoFisher), HIF1a (Proteintech), HDAC1 (Proteintech), (Bio-Rad) were used as secondary antibodies. Membranes were washed three times with 476 TBST and then incubated with Pierce ECL Plus Western Blotting Substrate (ThermoFisher). Blots were 477 imaged using the ChemiDoc MP Imager (Bio-Rad).

Statistical significance was determined by a two-tailed unpaired t-test, ****p£0.0001 F) 904 Schematic diagram of a MISTR network shows proposed interactions between the electron transport 905 chain complexes and vertebrate MISTR proteins (MISTRAV, MISTR1, MISTRH, vMISTRAV). MISTR loci 906 and RNA produced from them including miR-147b and miR-210 are also illustrated. Using the example 907 of infection as a stressor, MISTRAV transcription is induced by interferon (Figure 1D, Figure 3B) resulting 908 in the production of MISTRAV RNA. MISTRAV protein localizes to the mitochondria (Figure 1E), to 909 promote host defense. In the model, miR-147b production acts to inactivate MISTRAV translation and 910 downregulate MISTR1 to facilitate the apoptotic response (Figure 3 and Figure 5). Virus encoded variants 911 (vMISTRAV) counteract the response by inhibiting apoptosis through resemblance to MISTR 912 components. In the case of hypoxic stress, MISTRH and mir-210HG are transcribed from distinct loci to 913 produce MISTRH (Tello et al., 2011), which can inhibit Complex I activity (dashed red line), while miR-914 210 (Huang et al., 2009) downregulates MISTR1 to facilitate the cellular hypoxic response.
